Dialogue.Stage Direction: On a dark wet night, a woman climbs over a lovely set of wrought iron gates with a Danger Keep Out Unsafe Structure London County Council notice on them and goes up the gravel driveway to the big house. She breaks in through a boarded up window and takes photographs of the plastic covered chandeliers resting on the floors, and other pieces of furniture. Then she notices the letter B peeking from underneath a piece of peeling wallpaper. She pulls at it to reveal the words Beware the weeping angel. Underneath that is Oh, and duck! Really, duck! Sally Sparrow duck, now. So she ducks just before the window behind her is broken by a thrown pot, which bounces off the wall and breaks on the floor. The light of her torch reveals a statue outside, a winged angel with its hands covering its face. She goes back to the wall and pulls off more paper to reveal - Love from the Doctor (1969

metadata.title: The Warning
metadata.description: On a dark, wet night, Sally Sparrow climbs over a beautifully wrought iron gate, marked with a warning notice about the structure's unsafe condition. She proceeds up the gravel driveway towards the old house, breaking in through a boarded-up window. Inside the dimly lit interior, with plastic-covered chandeliers scattered on the floor, she takes photographs and becomes captivated by the eerie atmosphere. Sally’s attention is caught by a piece of peeling wallpaper, where she begins to reveal the message 'Beware the Weeping Angel'. She curiously continues to pull at the wallpaper, uncovering urgent instructions: 'Oh, and duck! Really, duck! Sally Sparrow duck, now.' Heeding the warning, she ducks just in time to avoid a pot thrown through the window behind her, shattering against the wall. A flash from her torch reveals the statue of a winged angel outside, its hands covering its face. Sally returns to the wall, pulls off more paper, and finds the message signed 'Love from the Doctor, 1969'.

key_dialogue: Love from the Doctor, 1969

Dialogue.Line: Yet. They're coming. They're coming for you, but listen, your life could depend on this. Don't blink. Don't even blink. Blink and you're dead. They are fast, faster than you can believe. Don't turn your back, don't look away, and don't blink. Good luck.

The emotional tone is one of anxiety mixed with determination as Sally grapples with the fantastical warning while realizing the gravity of the threat posed by the Weeping Angels.

metadata.title: The Letter from the Past
metadata.description: In the entrance hall of the old Wester Drumlins house, Sally Sparrow reads a letter from her friend Kathy, revealing the extraordinary connection between their lives. The atmosphere is tense and eerie, filled with a sense of foreboding as Sally discovers that she has a namesake from the past. She reacts with disbelief, feeling sick at the implications of the letter. As she reads, she becomes frantic, calling out for Kathy. Upon reaching the landing, she encounters three Weeping Angels, each adopting different positions, hiding their eyes. One of the statues is clutching a Yale key. As Sally crouches to inspect it, another statue reveals its eyes behind her. In a panic, she grabs the key, turns, and dashes down the stairs just in time to avoid being touched by the statue, which has now resumed its frozen position. She quickly retrieves the photographs and letters from the banister rail and runs outside, oblivious to the watching statues in the windows.

events.title: Kathy's Letter to Sally
events.description: Sally is reading a letter from Kathy, which reveals that if her grandson has done as promised, then her words are reaching Sally just moments after they last spoke. Kathy also shares how she named her youngest child Sally after Sally Sparrow.

For me, it has been over sixty years. The third of the photographs is of my children. The youngest is Sally. I named her after you, of course.

Kathy? Kathy! Kathy?

metadata.title: Messages from the Past
metadata.description: In a dim back room filled with old DVDs and flickering screens, Sally Sparrow is on the phone to the Doctor. She hears the Doctor's voice on the screen as he calls out for Martha, while Larry enters the room, still processing the situation. Sally and Larry engage in a conversation about Kathy and the message she left for him. Tension builds as they discuss the mysterious Doctor who is hidden across various DVDs, and the nature of time travel. Larry reveals he has a list of the seventeen DVDs that hold the Doctor's Easter eggs, hinting at the deeper connections between them and how time works. The atmosphere is a mix of light-hearted banter and the underlying tension of their precarious situation.

events.description: The Doctor expounds on his theory of time being non-linear and complex, continuing his lecture on the screen.
key_dialogue: People assume that time is a strict progression of cause to effect, but actually from a non-linear, non-subjective viewpoint, it's more like a big ball of wibbly-wobbly, timey-wimey stuff.

events.title: Sally Comments on the Doctor's Statement
events.description: Sally humorously reflects on the Doctor's explanation about time, noting the complexity.
key_dialogue: Started well, that sentence.

events.title: The Doctor Acknowledges Complexity
events.description: The Doctor acknowledges that his explanation about time got complicated.
key_dialogue: It got away from me, yeah.

events.title: Sally Expresses Confusion
events.description: Sally expresses confusion about the Doctor's ability to hear her.
key_dialogue: Okay, that's weird. Like you can hear me.

events.title: Doctor Confirms Hearing Sally
events.description: The Doctor confirms that he can hear Sally, further complicating the scenario.
key_dialogue: Well, I can hear you.

events.title: Sally Reacts to the Doctor's Awareness
events.description: Sally expresses shock and confusion over the Doctor's ability to hear her during a recorded message.
key_dialogue: Okay, that's enough! I've had enough now. I've had a long day and I've had bloody enough!

events.title: Larry Returns with the List
events.description: Larry returns from dealing with Banto, announcing he has the list of the seventeen DVDs.
key_dialogue: Got you the list.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Banto is talking to the film.

Dialogue.Line: Go to the police, you stupid woman. Why does nobody ever just go to the police?

metadata.title: Banto's Frustration
metadata.description: In the DVD store, Banto is engaged in an animated conversation with a television screen playing a film. The atmosphere is filled with the typical hustle of a small, slightly chaotic video store. He expresses his annoyance and disbelief at the lack of action from the characters in the film, sarcastically advising the female protagonist to go to the police instead of ignoring the situation. This scene captures Banto's frustration with the narrative choice of the characters within the film as well as his role as a commentator on the unfolding drama.

events.title: Banto's Frustration with Sally's Situation
events.description: Banto, a shopkeeper, expresses his frustration at the lack of common sense in the situation presented to him. He confronts the invisible recipient of his remarks, presumably Sally or the general public, criticizing them for not involving the police despite the evident danger.
key_dialogue: Go to the police, you stupid woman.
Why does nobody ever just go to the police?

Dialogue.Line: Look, I know how mad I'm sounding.
Shall we try it from the beginning this time?
Okay. There's this house. A big old house, been empty for years, falling apart. Wester Drumlins, out by the estate. You've probably seen it.
Could you just wait here for a minute?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The desk sergeant leaves her. Sally turns around to see two statues on the church opposite. She blinks, and they have disappeared.
They are either side of the window she is looking out of.

Dialogue.Line: Hi. DI Billy Shipton. Wester Drumlins, that's mine. Can't talk to you now, got a thing I can't be late for, so if you could just. Hello.
Eh, Marcie, can you tell them I'm going to be late for that thing?

metadata.title: Sally's Desperate Plea
metadata.description: The scene takes place inside a dimly lit police station, where SALLY nervously explains her bizarre experiences to the DESK SERGEANT. She describes the old, abandoned Wester Drumlins house, evoking an unsettling atmosphere with her details. As SALLY speaks, she peers out the window and notices two stone statues across the street. When she blinks, the statues vanish, heightening her sense of anxiety and disbelief. The entrance of BILLY, DI Shipton, brings a brief moment of chaos as he interrupts, indicating he is late for a matter, leaving SALLY in her fragile state of mind.

events.title: Sally Describes Wester Drumlins
events.description: Sally, in the police station, expresses her awareness of how mad she sounds. The desk sergeant, attempting to guide her, requests that they start over from the beginning as he is still unsure of the situation.
key_dialogue: Look, I know how mad I'm sounding.
Shall we try it from the beginning this time?

events.title: Sally Informs About the House
events.description: Sally continues her explanation, stating there is a big old house called Wester Drumlins that has been empty for years and is falling apart, prompting the desk sergeant to acknowledge the name.
key_dialogue: Okay. There's this house. A big old house, been empty for years, falling apart. Wester Drumlins, out by the estate. You've probably seen it.
Wester Drumlins?

events.title: Sally Sees Weeping Angels
events.description: Sally turns around and spots two statues (Weeping Angels) on the church opposite. When she blinks, they disappear, leading her to question her sanity.
key_dialogue: Okay, cracking up now.

events.title: Billy Shipton Enters
events.description: DI Billy Shipton enters the scene, introduces himself and informs Sally that he can't talk at the moment due to a time-sensitive matter. He requests someone named Marcie to inform his team of his tardiness.
key_dialogue: Hi. DI Billy Shipton. Wester Drumlins, that's mine. Can't talk to you now, got a thing I can't be late for, so if you could just...
Marcie, can you tell them I'm going to be late for that thing?

Dialogue.Line: Over the last two years, yeah. They all still have personal items in them and a couple still had the motor running.
So over the last two years, the owners of all of these vehicles have driven up to Wester Drumlins House, parked outside and just disappeared.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a 1960's style police box in the corner.

Dialogue.Line: Ah! The pride of the Wester Drumlins collection. We found that there, too. Somebody's idea of a joke, I suppose.
But what is it? What's a police box?

Well, it's a special kind of phone box for policemen. They used to have them all over. But this isn't a real one. The phone's just a dummy, and the windows are the wrong size. We can't even get in it. Ordinary Yale lock, but nothing fits. But that's not the big question. See, you're missing the big question.
Will you have a drink with me?
Aren't you on duty, Detective Inspector Shipton?
Nope. Knocked off before I left. Told them I had a family crisis.
Because life is short and you are hot. Drink?
Moving kind of fast, DI Shipton.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She writes in a notebook.

Dialogue.Line: Just my phone number. Not a promise. Not a guarantee. Not an IOU. Just a phone number.
Sally Shipton. Sparrow! Sally Sparrow. I'm going now. Don't look at me.
Definitely going to phone you, gorgeous girl!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sally leaves. There are four angel statues around the Tardis. One has its hand up to the lock. He walks around, looking at them, then blinks.

metadata.title: Unraveling Mysteries
metadata.description: In an underground car park, SALLY and BILLY stand beside a collection of abandoned vehicles, each still containing personal items. The atmosphere is tense yet filled with curiosity as they discuss the peculiar disappearances linked to the nearby Wester Drumlins House. A 1960's style police box sits in the corner, enhancing the mystery of the scene. As they converse, BILLY tries to engage SALLY with a personal invitation for a drink, showcasing a moment of light-heartedness amidst the grim context. Despite the strange and eerie situation, an unexpected spark of flirtation arises between them, highlighting SALLY's cool demeanor. The scene ends as BILLY gazes at the statues, oblivious to the looming danger of the Weeping Angels surrounding the TARDIS, escalating the tension in a seemingly trivial moment.

events.title: Sally Questions the Vehicles
events.description: Sally inquires about the vehicles parked in the garage. Billy explains that all the vehicles have been there for the last two years, with personal items still inside and some even having the motors running.
key_dialogue: SALLY: All of them?
BILLY: Over the last two years, yeah. They all still have personal items in them and a couple still had the motor running.

events.title: Sally Realizes the Disappearances
events.description: Sally comes to the conclusion that the owners of the vehicles must have driven up to Wester Drumlins House and disappeared, raising a sense of dread about the mysteries surrounding the place.
key_dialogue: SALLY: So over the last two years, the owners of all of these vehicles have driven up to Wester Drumlins House, parked outside and just disappeared.

events.title: Discovery of the Police Box
events.description: Sally notices a 1960s style police box in the corner of the car park, prompting her to ask about it. Billy describes it as the pride of the Wester Drumlins collection, noting it was found at the scene.
key_dialogue: SALLY: What's that?
BILLY: Ah! The pride of the Wester Drumlins collection. We found that there, too. Somebody's idea of a joke, I suppose.

events.title: Explanation of the Police Box
events.description: Billy explains that the police box is not a real one; its phone is a dummy, the windows are the wrong size, and they can't get in. He adds that the big question is still not addressed, hinting at his feelings for Sally.
key_dialogue: SALLY: But what is it? What's a police box?

BILLY: Well, it's a special kind of phone box for policemen. They used to have them all over. But this isn't a real one. The phone's just a dummy, and the windows are the wrong size. We can't even get in it.

events.title: Billy Asks Sally Out
events.description: Billy, feeling bold, asks Sally out for a drink, indicating his attraction to her. Sally is surprised and a little hesitant, leading to an exchange where she ultimately does not accept but provides her phone number.
key_dialogue: BILLY: Will you have a drink with me?
SALLY: I'm sorry?
BILLY: Drink? You? Me? Now?

events.title: Sally Hesitates and Shares Her Number
events.description: Sally initially rejects Billy's invitation but after some playful banter, she writes down her phone number for him, clarifying that it is just her number and not a promise or guarantee.
key_dialogue: SALLY: Just my phone number. Not a promise. Not a guarantee. Not an IOU. Just a phone number.

events.title: Billy's Persistent Interest
events.description: Billy continues to express interest in Sally as he asks if he can phone her. Sally playfully insists that he shouldn't look at her, highlighting the tension between them and Billy's growing affection for her.
key_dialogue: BILLY: I'll phone you.
SALLY: Don't look at me.

events.title: Billy Bids Farewell
events.description: As Sally prepares to leave, Billy makes one final attempt to connect, promising to definitely call her which elicits a playfully reticent response from Sally. After she exits, Billy is left staring at the mysterious weeping angels.
key_dialogue: BILLY: Definitely going to phone you, gorgeous girl!
SALLY: You definitely better!

events.title: Billy Blinks in the Presence of Angels
events.description: After Sally leaves, Billy is left alone with four weeping angels surrounding the TARDIS. Without noticing the danger, he blinks, which implies a shift in tension, making the scene more suspenseful.

metadata.title: The Yale Key Revelation
metadata.description: In an urban setting at night, following a tense encounter at the police station, Sally Sparrow crosses the street. The atmosphere is one of urgency and apprehension. She pauses to take out a Yale key from her coat pocket, an important item that symbolizes hope and connection to the Doctor. Meanwhile, the voice of DI Billy Shipton echoes in the background, noting the ordinary nature of the Yale lock, emphasizing its significance. Suddenly, a sense of dread washes over her as she realizes she runs back to the car park but finds the TARDIS, Billy, and the statues have vanished, leaving her in a state of confusion and worry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Billy slides down a wall.

Dialogue.Line: 1969. Not bad, as it goes. You've got the moon landing to look forward to.
Oh, the moon landing's brilliant. We went four times, back when we had transport.

The same way we did. The touch of an angel. Same one, probably, since you ended up in the same year. No, no. No, no, no, don't get up. Time travel without a capsule. Nasty. Catch your breath. Don't go swimming for half an hour.

Fascinating race, the Weeping Angels. The only psychopaths in the universe to kill you nicely. No mess, no fuss, they just zap you into the past and let you live to death. The rest of your life used up and blown away in the blink of an eye. You die in the past, and in the present they consume the energy of all the days you might have had. All your stolen moments. They're creatures of the abstract. They live off potential energy.
What in God's name are you talking about?
Trust me. Just nod when he stops for breath.

Tracked you down with this. This is my timey-wimey detector. It goes ding when there's stuff. Also, it can boil an egg at thirty paces, whether you want it to or not, actually, so I've learned to stay away from hens. It's not pretty when they blow.
I don't understand. Where am I?
Normally, I'd offer you a lift home, but somebody nicked my motor. So I need you to take a message to Sally Sparrow. And I'm sorry, Billy. I am very, very sorry. It's going to take you a while.

metadata.title: Time Travel and Messages
metadata.description: In a dimly lit alleyway, BILLY, disoriented and confused, slides down a wall. The DOCTOR greets him and informs him that it's 1969, suggesting that he has a bright future with the upcoming moon landing. MARTHA, standing by, adds that they have traveled to the moon multiple times before. The DOCTOR explains the bizarre circumstances of Billy's arrival, attributing it to the Weeping Angels, who can send people back in time while feeding off their potential energy. BILLY expresses his bewilderment, prompting MARTHA to suggest that he simply nod while the DOCTOR explains. The DOCTOR introduces his quirky timey-wimey detector, a device that highlights the absurdity of their situation. He then informs BILLY that he cannot offer a ride home due to his transportation being stolen and instead asks him to relay a message to Sally Sparrow. The scene is infused with a mix of humor and urgency as the characters grapple with the implications of time travel.

events.title: Billy's Awakening in 1969
events.description: Billy slides down a wall and expresses confusion about where he is. The Doctor explains that he has arrived in 1969 and reassures him that there are exciting events, such as the moon landing, to look forward to.
key_dialogue: BILLY: Where am I?
DOCTOR: 1969. Not bad, as it goes. You've got the moon landing to look forward to.

events.title: The Doctor's Explanation
events.description: The Doctor explains to Billy how he arrived in 1969 by mentioning the 'touch of an angel' and warns him not to get up due to the side effects of time travel without a capsule.
key_dialogue: DOCTOR: The same way we did. The touch of an angel. Same one, probably, since you ended up in the same year.
DOCTOR: No, no. No, no, no, don't get up. Time travel without a capsule. Nasty. Catch your breath.

events.title: The Doctor Describes the Weeping Angels
events.description: The Doctor provides a detailed explanation of the Weeping Angels. He describes them as the only creatures that 'kill you nicely', explaining how they zap victims into the past and live off the potential energy of those stolen moments.
key_dialogue: DOCTOR: Fascinating race, the Weeping Angels. The only psychopaths in the universe to kill you nicely. No mess, no fuss...
DOCTOR: They die in the past, and in the present they consume the energy of all the days you might have had.

events.title: Martha's Advice
events.description: Martha intervenes during the conversation, offering advice for Billy to just nod when the Doctor stops speaking, indicating her awareness of the Doctor's tendencies.
key_dialogue: MARTHA: Trust me. Just nod when he stops for breath.

events.title: The Doctor's Timey-Wimey Detector
events.description: The Doctor introduces his improvised 'timey-wimey detector', explaining its capabilities and the comedic implications of its design.
key_dialogue: DOCTOR: Tracked you down with this. This is my timey-wimey detector. It goes ding when there's stuff.
DOCTOR: It can boil an egg at thirty paces, whether you want it to or not.

events.title: Billy's Confusion
events.description: Billy expresses confusion regarding his situation once more, seeking reassurance and clarity about his whereabouts.
key_dialogue: BILLY: I don't understand. Where am I?
MARTHA: 1969, like he says.

events.title: The Message for Sally Sparrow
events.description: The Doctor conveys to Billy the importance of delivering a message to Sally Sparrow, apologizing for the delay involved.
key_dialogue: DOCTOR: Normally, I'd offer you a lift home, but somebody nicked my motor. So I need you to take a message to Sally Sparrow.
DOCTOR: And I'm sorry, Billy. I am very, very sorry. It's going to take you a while.

metadata.title: A Mysterious Call
metadata.description: In an underground car park, dimly lit and echoing, Sally Sparrow stands alone, her mobile phone ringing loudly in the stillness. As she answers the call, a mix of concern and urgency fills her voice. She asks Billy where he is and reveals her growing anxiety about the situation. The atmosphere is tense, marked by the faint sounds of dripping water and distant echoes, emphasizing the isolation of the parking structure. Sally's demeanor showcases a mix of determination and fear as she seeks answers amid the unfolding mystery.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Just one bed is occupied, by the window.
The old man in the bed wakes up.

Dialogue.Line: It was raining when we met.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A little later, Sally looks at Billy's wedding photograph.

Dialogue.Line: Sally Shipton. I often thought about looking for you before tonight, but apparently it would've torn a hole in the fabric of space and time, and destroyed two thirds of the universe. Also, I'd lost my hair.
Two thirds of the universe. Where'd you get that from?
There's a man in 1969. He sent me with a message for you.
Just this. Look at the list.
What does that mean? Is that it? Look at the list?
He said you'd have it by now. A list of seventeen DVDs. I didn't stay a policeman back then. Got into publishing. Then video publishing. Then DVDs, of course.
You put the Easter Egg on.
Have you noticed what all seventeen DVDs have in common yet? I suppose it's hard for you, in a way.
How could the Doctor have even known I had a list? I only just got this.
I asked him how, but he said he couldn't tell me. He said you'd understand it one day, but that I never would.
Soon as I understand it, I'll come and tell you.
No, gorgeous girl, you can't. There's only tonight. He told me all those years ago that we'll only meet again this one time. On the night I die.
It's kept me going. I'm an old, sick man. But I've had something to look forward to. Ah, life is long, and you are hot. Oh, look at my hands. They're old man's hands. How did that happen?
I'll stay. I'm going to stay with you, okay?
Thank you, Sally Sparrow. I have till the rain stops.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Later, the rain has stopped and the bed is empty. Sally leaves the hospital.

metadata.title: A Final Encounter
metadata.description: In the quiet atmosphere of a geriatric ward, a single occupied bed is illuminated by the light streaming through a window. SALLY approaches the bed, awakening BILLY, who softly recalls the moment they first met, reflecting on the rain that accompanied their encounter. Their conversation drifts into nostalgia as SALLY looks at a photograph, which prompts BILLY to reminisce about his late wife, also named Sally. BILLY reveals the reason for his visit, carrying a message from the Doctor, instructing SALLY to 'look at the list.' As they discuss the significance of a list of seventeen DVDs, SALLY grapples with the mystery of how the Doctor could know her belongings. BILLY, understanding the gravity of their meeting, shares that this is their last encounter before his passing, emphasizing the importance of their shared memories. The scene captures a poignant moment as SALLY vows to stay with BILLY until the end, only to later discover his bed empty after the rain stops, signifying his departure.

SALLY: Oh, Billy.

The interior is dimly lit, showcasing an old and somewhat eerie home that evokes thoughts of classic horror films. As Larry steps in, he remarks with a hint of humor, referring to the house as resembling 'Scooby Doo's house', highlighting its spooky charm. Sally quickly clarifies that she does not live there, dismissing his comment, but her tone suggests an underlying tension about the house's mysterious reputation. This brief yet light exchange juxtaposes the ominous nature of their surroundings, reflecting the blending of humor and horror in their adventure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry puts a DVD into his portable player.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, this is the one with the clearest sound. Slightly better picture quality on this one, but I don't know
No, it sounds like he's replying, but he always says that.
He can hear us. Oh, my God, you can really hear us?
Of course he can't hear us. Look, I've got a transcript. See? Everything he says. Yup, that's me. Yes, I do. Yup, and this. Next it's
Are you going to read out the whole thing?
I'm a time traveller. Or I was. I'm stuck in 1969.
We're stuck. All of space and time, he promised me. Now I've got a job in a shop. I've got to support him!
But you're replying to me. You can't know exactly what I'm going to say, forty years before I say it.
I'm getting this down. I'm writing in your bits.
How? How is this possible? Tell me.
People don't understand time. It's not what you think it is.
I'm clever and I'm listening. And don't patronise me because people have died, and I'm not happy. Tell me.
People assume that time is a strict progression of cause to effect, but actually from a non-linear, non-subjective viewpoint, it's more like a big ball of wibbly wobbly, timey-wimey stuff.
Yeah, I've seen this bit before. You said that sentence got away from you.
It got away from me, yeah.
Next thing you're going to say is, well I can hear you.
Well, not hear you, exactly, but I know everything you're going to say.
Always gives me the shivers, that bit.
How can you know what I'm going to say?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Where Larry is sitting on the floor, writing.

Dialogue.Line: What does he mean by look to your left? I've written tons about that on the forums. I think it's a political statement.
He means you. What are you doing?
I'm writing in your bits. That way I've got a complete transcript of the whole conversation. Wait until this hits the net. This will explode the egg forums.
I've got a copy of the finished transcript. It's on my autocue.
How can you have a copy of the finished transcript? It's still being written.
I told you. I'm a time traveller. I got it in the future.
Okay, let me get my head round this. You're reading aloud from a transcript of a conversation you're still having.
Never mind that. You can do shorthand?
What matters is, we can communicate. We have got big problems now. They have taken the blue box, haven't they? The angels have the phone box.
The angels have the phone box. That's my favourite, I've got it on a t-shirt.
What do you mean, angels? You mean those statue things?

The lonely assassins, they used to be called. No one quite knows where they came from, but they're as old as the universe, or very nearly, and they have survived this long because they have the most perfect defence system ever evolved. They are quantum-locked. They don't exist when they're being observed. The moment they are seen by any other living creature, they freeze into rock. No choice. It's a fact of their biology. In the sight of any living thing, they literally turn to stone. And you can't kill a stone. Of course, a stone can't kill you either. But then you turn your head away, then you blink, and oh yes it can.
Don't take your eyes off that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is an Angel close by.

Dialogue.Line: That's why they cover their eyes. They're not weeping. They can't risk looking at each other. Their greatest asset is their greatest curse. They can never be seen. The loneliest creatures in the universe. And I'm sorry. I am very, very sorry. It's up to you now.
What am I supposed to do?
The blue box, it's my time machine. There is a world of time energy in there they could feast on forever, but the damage they could do could switch off the sun. You have got to send it back to me.

And that's it, I'm afraid. There's no more from you on the transcript, that's the last I've got. I don't know what stopped you talking, but I can guess. They're coming. The angels are coming for you. But listen, your life could depend on this. Don't blink. Don't even blink. Blink and you're dead. They are fast. Faster than you can believe. Don't turn your back, don't look away, and don't blink. Good luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The picture freezes.

Dialogue.Line: What good would that do? You're not looking at the statue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Angel is towering over them, reaching out, mouth wide open. They back away.

Dialogue.Line: Keep looking at it. Keep looking at it.
There's just one, right, there's just this one. We're okay if we just keep staring at this one statue. Everything's going to be fine.
They were upstairs before, but I think I heard them moving.
Moving where? Three of them? Moving where?
I'm going to look around. I'm going to check. You keep looking at this one. Don't blink. Remember what he said. Don't even blink.
Who blinks? I'm too scared to blink.
Okay, we're going to the door. The front door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sally guides Larry backwards to the doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Okay. We can't both get to the front door without taking our eyes off that thing, so you stay here.
I'll be just round the corner. You stay here. They've locked it. They've locked us in!
The key. I took it last time I was here. They followed me to get it back. I led them to the blue box. Now they've got that.
I'm going to check the back door. You wait here.
Give them the key! Give them what they want! Sally, no. What if they come behind me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry looks behind him briefly to check where the doorway is, and when he turns back the Angel is inches from his face.

Dialogue.Line: Sally, please, I can't do this! Sally, hurry up! Where are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He backs away through the doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Larry? They've blocked off the back door, but there's a cellar. There might be a way out. A delivery hatch or something.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry backs away round the corner.

metadata.title: The Doctor's Message
metadata.description: In the drawing room of Wester Drumlins, Sally and Larry engage in a tense conversation as Larry prepares to play a DVD featuring the Doctor. As they watch, the Doctor speaks to them from the screen, seemingly responding to their questions. Sally becomes increasingly anxious as she realizes the Doctor can predict their words. The Doctor explains the nature of time, emphasizing its complexity and the danger posed by the Weeping Angels. Meanwhile, the tension builds as the Angels draw closer, threatening their safety. Larry holds a transcript of the Doctor's dialogue, detailing the unfolding situation while uncertainty looms in the air. The emotional tone is a mix of fear, urgency, and intrigue as the characters grapple with overwhelming knowledge and impending danger.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis is here, with its three guardian Angels.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, boys, I know how this works. You can't move so long as I can see you. Whole world in the box, the Doctor says. Hope he's not lying, because I don't see how else we're getting out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry runs past her. The Angel from upstairs is now behind them.

Dialogue.Line: Why's it pointing at the light?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The light bulb flickers as they go to the Tardis, back to back.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my God, it's turning out the lights.
Sally, hurry up! Get it open! They're getting closer. Sally, come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the flickering light, the snarling Angels are getting nearer.

metadata.title: Tension in the Cellar
metadata.description: In a dimly lit cellar, Sally and Larry face a growing threat as three Weeping Angels slowly advance towards them while they're trying to access the TARDIS. Sally, determined and resourceful, asserts that the Angels cannot move as long as she can see them. She expresses hope in the Doctor's promise of safety inside the TARDIS. Amidst flickering lights and growing tension, Sally struggles to find the lock to open the TARDIS, while the presence of the snarling Angels heightens their panic. Larry shouts for her to hurry as the flickering light intensifies the dread, indicating that the Angels are getting closer.

events.title: Sally Confronts the Weeping Angels
events.description: Sally asserts her understanding of the Weeping Angels' behavior, claiming they cannot move as long as she can see them. She expresses skepticism about the Doctor's reliability and notes the presence of the TARDIS as their only means of escape.
key_dialogue: Okay, boys, I know how this works. You can't move so long as I can see you.
Whole world in the box, the Doctor says. Hope he's not lying because I don't see how else we're getting out.

events.title: Larry Notices the Weeping Angel
events.description: Larry, in panic, observes and questions why one of the Weeping Angels is pointing at the light. This moment heightens the urgency as they realize the Angels are manipulating their environment.
key_dialogue: Oh, and there's your one.
Why's it pointing at the light?

events.title: Lights Flicker and Tension Escalates
events.description: As Sally and Larry prepare to reach the TARDIS, they notice the flickering of the light bulb. This flickering signifies the impending danger from the Angels as they attempt to dim the light to close in on their prey.
key_dialogue: Oh, my God, it's turning out the lights.

events.title: Urgent Call for Action
events.description: Larry urges Sally to hurry and open the TARDIS as they feel the threat of the Weeping Angels closing in. There is a palpable sense of panic and escalating danger as they realize the severity of their situation.
key_dialogue: Quickly!
Sally, hurry up! Get it open! They're getting closer. Sally, come on!

events.description: Sally frantically attempts to find the lock on the TARDIS amidst the chaotic situation and growing urgency. Her efforts are hindered by the flickering lights and proximity of the Angels, causing a growing sense of desperation.
key_dialogue: It won't turn!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An image appears on an upper catwalk.

Dialogue.Line: This is security protocol seven one two. This time capsule has detected the presence of an authorised control disc, valid one journey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry takes out the DVD case he put in his pocket and opens it. The DVD glows.

Dialogue.Line: Please insert the disc and prepare for departure.
Looks like a DVD player. There's a slot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Angels attack the Tardis.
As the Tardis rocks to and fro, Larry gets the DVD into the slot. The time rotor starts up.
Just the Tardis itself dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my God, it's leaving us behind. Doctor, no! You can't!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They can see the Angels that are around the Tardis, arms and mouths wide and not covering their eyes.
The Tardis is gone.

Dialogue.Line: Look at them! Quick, look at them!
I don't think we need to. He tricked them, The Doctor tricked them. They're looking at each other. They're never going to move again.

metadata.title: The TARDIS Departure
metadata.description: In the TARDIS, a holographic image of the Doctor activates, indicating that the time capsule has detected an authorised control disc for a single journey. Sally, noticing the glowing DVD, identifies the slot for insertion. As they prepare for departure, the Weeping Angels begin to attack the TARDIS, prompting urgency from both Sally and Larry. Larry successfully inserts the DVD, initiating the TARDIS's dematerialisation process. As the TARDIS begins to fade away, Sally panics, believing they are being left behind. In a moment of realization, Larry observes the Angels are now looking at each other, implying they are frozen in place and will never move again.

events.title: Hologram Doctor Activates Security Protocol
events.description: The hologram of the Doctor appears, stating that the TARDIS has detected an authorized control disc and is ready for departure. Larry takes out the glowing DVD he previously pocketed.
key_dialogue: DOCTOR [hologram]: This is security protocol seven one two. This time capsule has detected the presence of an authorised control disc, valid one journey.
DOCTOR [hologram]: Please insert the disc and prepare for departure.

events.description: With urgency heightened, Larry successfully inserts the glowing DVD into the TARDIS disc slot amidst the chaos of the Angels' attack.
key_dialogue: SALLY: Well, hurry up then!
LARRY: What's happening?

events.title: TARDIS Begins to Dematerialize
events.description: As Larry inserts the DVD, the TARDIS begins to dematerialize. Sally realizes with horror that they are being left behind.
key_dialogue: SALLY: Oh, my God, it's leaving us behind. Doctor, no! You can't!

events.title: Confrontation with the Angels
events.description: Realizing the threat, Sally commands Larry to observe the Weeping Angels as they momentarily reveal their true nature, menacing and ready to attack.
key_dialogue: SALLY: Look at them! Quick, look at them!
LARRY: I don't think we need to. He tricked them, The Doctor tricked them. They're looking at each other. They're never going to move again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One year later.

Dialogue.Line: Can you mind the shop? I'm just nipping next door for some milk.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She has a folder containing the conversation transcript, Kathy's photographs and letter, and also a picture of an Angel covering its eyes.

Dialogue.Line: Sally, can't you let it go?
Of course I can't let it go.
How did the Doctor know where to write the words on the wall? How could he get a copy of the transcript? Where did he get all that information from?
Look, some things you never find out. And that's okay.
Ever think this might be getting in the way of other things?
We just run a shop together. That's all it is, just a shop.
Anyway, milk. Back in a mo.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry leaves. A taxi pulls up outside. Martha and the Doctor get out and start to go down the street. Sally runs outside.

metadata.title: Letting Go
metadata.description: In a cozy DVD store, one year after the events with the Weeping Angels, Larry asks Sally to mind the shop while he nips next door for milk. Sally, holding a folder containing a transcript of a conversation, photographs of Kathy, and an image of a Weeping Angel, is confronted by Larry about her obsession with the past. As he expresses concern that Sally's fixation might be interfering with their relationship, she insists she cannot let go of the unexplainable events surrounding the Doctor. Larry leaves for the milk, and as he exits, a taxi pulls up outside, revealing the Doctor and Martha, prompting Sally to rush outside to see them.

events.title: Larry Requests to Mind the Shop
events.description: Larry asks Sally to mind the shop while he nips next door for some milk. Sally agrees without worries.
key_dialogue: LARRY: Can you mind the shop? I'm just nipping next door for some milk.
SALLY: Yeah. No worries.

events.title: Sally's Attempt to Conceal the Folder
events.description: Sally tries to hide a folder containing significant documents, including a conversation transcript, photographs of Kathy, and a picture of an Angel covering its eyes, from Larry.
key_dialogue: LARRY: What's this?
SALLY: Nothing.

events.title: Larry Questions Sally's Obsession
events.description: Larry expresses concern about Sally's inability to let go of the past and her obsession with the events involving the Doctor and the Weeping Angels.
key_dialogue: LARRY: Sally, can't you let it go?
LARRY: This is over.

events.title: Sally's Determination to Uncover the Truth
events.description: Sally questions how the Doctor obtained information about her and the writing on the wall, emphasizing her frustration at not knowing the answers.
key_dialogue: SALLY: How did the Doctor know where to write the words on the wall? How could he get a copy of the transcript? Where did he get all that information from?

events.title: Larry's Attempt to Comfort Sally
events.description: Larry tries to comfort Sally by suggesting that some things are meant to remain a mystery, expressing that it is okay not to have all the answers.
key_dialogue: LARRY: Look, some things you never find out. And that's okay.

events.title: Sally Rejects Larry's Comfort
events.description: Sally firmly rejects Larry's assertion that it's okay not to know, indicating she feels strongly about resolving the lingering doubts.
key_dialogue: SALLY: No, it isn't.

events.title: Larry Hints at Relationship Issues
events.description: Larry suggests that Sally's fixation on the past may be impacting their relationship, hinting at feelings of distance between them.
key_dialogue: LARRY: Ever think this might be getting in the way of other things?

events.title: Sally's Denial of Relationship Depth
events.description: Sally insists that their connection is merely a working relationship, dismissing Larry's implication about their status.
key_dialogue: SALLY: We just run a shop together. That's all it is, just a shop.

events.title: Larry Leaves for Milk
events.description: Larry responds to Sally's insistence by saying he will head out for milk, attempting to remove himself from the tense conversation.
key_dialogue: LARRY: Anyway, milk. Back in a mo.

events.title: The Doctor and Martha Arrive
events.description: As Larry leaves, a taxi pulls up outside, from which Martha and the Doctor emerge, heading down the street.

events.title: Sally Rushes to the Doctor
events.description: Sally, noticing the Doctor and Martha, rushes outside in excitement to catch up with them, signaling the end of the scene.
key_dialogue: SALLY: Doctor! Doctor!!

Dialogue.Line: Hello. Sorry, bit of a rush. There's a sort of thing happening. Fairly important we stop it.
My God, it's you. It really is you. Oh, you don't remember me, do you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Martha is carrying a quiver of arrows, and the Doctor has a long bow.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, we haven't have time for this. The migration's started.

Look, sorry, I've got a bit of a complex life. Things don't always happen to me in quite the right order. Gets a bit confusing at times, especially at weddings. I'm rubbish at weddings, especially my own.
Oh, my God, of course. You're a time traveller. It hasn't happened to you yet. None of it. It's still in your future.
Doctor, please. Twenty minutes to red hatching.
It was me. Oh, for God's sake, it was me all along. You got it all from me.
Okay, listen. One day you're going to get stuck in 1969. Make sure you've got this with you. You're going to need it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sally hands her file of documents to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Yeah, listen, listen, got to dash. Things happening. Well, four things. Well, four things and a lizard.
Okay. No worries. On you go. See you around some day.
Good to meet you, Sally Sparrow.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry returns with the milk. Sally takes his hand.
Sally and Larry go back into the DVD store, now retitled Sparrow and Nightingale, Antiquarian Books and Rare DVDs. The camera pans up to the next building where a grotesque is sitting on the roof.
Montage of public statuary.

Dialogue.Line: Blink and you're dead. Don't turn your back. Don't look away. And don't blink. Good luck.

metadata.title: The Doctor Returns
metadata.description: Outside the DVD store, a hurried exchange occurs between Sally Sparrow and the Doctor. It’s a bustling urban setting where the Doctor, equipped with a long bow and accompanied by Martha who carries a quiver of arrows, is caught off-guard by Sally's excited recognition. Despite the urgency of their mission, Sally reveals the significance of their past encounters and hands over crucial documents, linking their fates through time travel. The emotional tone is a mixture of exhilaration and urgency, as Sally grapples with the realization of her pivotal role in the Doctor's timeline. The scene culminates in bittersweet farewells as Sally and Larry, now partners in life and business, step back into their bookstore while the Doctor rushes off into another adventure.

events.title: Sally Calls Out to the Doctor
events.description: Sally Sparrow frantically calls out to the Doctor, signaling her urgency and excitement upon seeing him.
key_dialogue: Doctor! Doctor! Doctor!

events.title: The Doctor Acknowledges Sally
events.description: The Doctor responds to Sally, acknowledging her call but indicating he is in a rush due to a pressing situation.
key_dialogue: Hello. Sorry, bit of a rush. There's a sort of thing happening. Fairly important we stop it.

events.title: Sally Recognizes the Doctor
events.description: Sally expresses her astonishment at reuniting with the Doctor, realizing he does not remember her.
key_dialogue: My God, it's you. It really is you. Oh, you don't remember me, do you?

events.title: Martha Urges the Doctor to Move On
events.description: Martha Jones interrupts the conversation, reminding the Doctor of the urgency of their current mission regarding the migration.
key_dialogue: Doctor, we haven't have time for this. The migration's started.

events.title: Doctor Explains His Time Travel Complexity
events.description: The Doctor explains his complex life as a time traveler, indicating that events in his life do not occur in a linear order.
key_dialogue: I've got a bit of a complex life. Things don't always happen to me in quite the right order.

events.title: Sally Concludes the Doctor is a Time Traveller
events.description: Sally realizes the implications of the Doctor being a time traveler, understanding that his experiences with her and others are yet to happen in his timeline.
key_dialogue: Oh, my God, of course. You're a time traveller. It hasn't happened to you yet. None of it. It's still in your future.

events.title: Martha Pushes for Urgency
events.description: Martha continues to insist that they need to leave quickly due to an impending event called 'red hatching'.
key_dialogue: Doctor, please. Twenty minutes to red hatching.

events.title: Sally Realizes Her Role
events.description: Sally comes to the realization that her actions and choices have been central to the Doctor's timeline and past events.
key_dialogue: It was me. Oh, for God's sake, it was me all along. You got it all from me.

events.title: The Doctor inquires About the Information
events.description: The Doctor expresses curiosity about what Sally is referring to when she claims he got everything from her.
key_dialogue: Got what?

events.title: Sally Hands Over the File to the Doctor
events.description: Sally hands over a file containing important information to the Doctor, emphasizing its significance for his future.
key_dialogue: One day you're going to get stuck in 1969. Make sure you've got this with you. You're going to need it.

events.title: Martha Calls for the Doctor's Attention
events.description: Martha interrupts again, reminding the Doctor that they need to leave immediately.
key_dialogue: Doctor!

events.title: The Doctor Exits in a Hurry
events.description: The Doctor hurriedly leaves after acknowledging Sally’s name, which leaves her with a mix of emotions.
key_dialogue: Look, got to dash. Things happening. Well, four things. Well, four things and a lizard.

events.title: Sally Provides Her Name
events.description: Sally introduces herself to the Doctor, which signifies a personal connection amid the chaos.
key_dialogue: Sally Sparrow.

events.title: The Doctor Acknowledges Sally
events.description: The Doctor acknowledges Sally's introduction with a polite greeting, creating a moment of mutual recognition.
key_dialogue: Good to meet you, Sally Sparrow.

events.title: Larry Returns With Milk
events.description: Larry reappears with a carton of milk, joining Sally in her exit from the scene with the Doctor.
key_dialogue: Larry returns with milk.

events.title: Sally Says Goodbye to the Doctor
events.description: Sally bids farewell to the Doctor as she and Larry prepare to return to their lives, closing the chapter of their encounter.
key_dialogue: Goodbye, Doctor.
